kg.definition: Newborn jaundice is a common condition in newborns characterized by the yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood.

treatment.description: Using light to help break down bilirubin in the skin.

treatment.description: A procedure to replace the baby's blood with donor blood in severe cases.

treatment.description: Encouraging more frequent breastfeeding to promote bilirubin elimination.

prevention: Monitoring bilirubin levels in at-risk infants
kg.prognosis: Most cases of newborn jaundice are mild and resolve without treatment within a few weeks.

CA-125 is a protein that is a biomarker used primarily to monitor treatment response and disease progression in ovarian cancer.

biomarker.definition: A biological molecule found in blood, other body fluids, or tissues that is a sign of a normal or abnormal process, or of a condition or disease.

clinical_uses.description: CA-125 levels can indicate how well the body is responding to treatment in patients with ovarian cancer.
Elevated CA-125 levels may suggest that the cancer is progressing or recurring.

normal_levels.description: Normal CA-125 levels are typically considered to be below 35 U/mL.

factors_affecting_levels.description: CA-125 levels can be elevated during menstruation.
Pregnancy can also lead to increased CA-125 levels.
Conditions such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and liver disease can affect CA-125 levels.

limitations.description: CA-125 is not exclusively a marker for ovarian cancer and can be elevated in other conditions.
limitations.note: It should not be used as a standalone diagnostic tool.

kg.definition: A series of surgical procedures to treat hypoplastic left heart syndrome, a congenital heart defect.

related_conditions.name: Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome
related_conditions.description: A congenital heart defect where the left side of the heart is underdeveloped.

related_conditions.name: Aortic Stenosis
related_conditions.description: Narrowing of the aortic valve opening, which can affect blood flow from the heart.

surgical_procedures.name: Norwood Procedure
surgical_procedures.description: The first surgery performed in the treatment of HLHS, usually done within the first week of life.

surgical_procedures.name: Glenn Procedure
surgical_procedures.description: The second surgery, typically performed between 4 to 6 months of age, connecting the superior vena cava to the pulmonary artery.

surgical_procedures.name: Fontan Procedure
surgical_procedures.description: The final surgery, usually performed between 18 months to 4 years of age, redirecting blood flow to the lungs.

diagnostic_methods.name: Echocardiogram
diagnostic_methods.description: An ultrasound of the heart to visualize its structure and function.

diagnostic_methods.name: Chest X-ray
diagnostic_methods.description: An imaging test to check for heart size and blood flow.

diagnostic_methods.name: Cardiac MRI
diagnostic_methods.description: An advanced imaging technique to provide detailed information about heart anatomy.

treatment_options.name: Surgical Repair
treatment_options.description: The primary treatment involving multiple surgeries to improve heart function.

treatment_options.name: Medications
treatment_options.description: Drugs to manage symptoms and improve heart function, such as diuretics and beta-blockers.

treatment_options.name: Heart Transplant
treatment_options.description: In severe cases, a heart transplant may be necessary if surgical repair is not viable.

prognosis.description: With successful surgical intervention, many children can lead a relatively normal life, but they require ongoing medical care.

kg.definition: Legal documents that allow individuals to outline their preferences for medical treatment in case they become unable to communicate their wishes.

types.description: A document that specifies what medical treatments an individual does or does not want in end-of-life situations.

types.type: Durable Power of Attorney for Health Care
types.description: A document that designates a person to make medical decisions on behalf of an individual if they are incapacitated.

legal_aspects.validity: Varies by state or country; must often be signed and witnessed.
legal_aspects.revocation: Can be revoked at any time by the individual.

importance: Ensures that medical treatment aligns with the individual's values and preferences.
Reduces the burden on family members to make difficult decisions during crises.

kg.definition: The male reproductive organs that are involved in sexual reproduction and urinary function.

penis.description: The external organ used for sexual intercourse and urination.

parts.shaft: The elongated part of the penis.
parts.glans: The sensitive tip of the penis, also known as the head.
parts.urethra: The tube that carries urine and semen out of the body.

scrotum.description: The pouch of skin that contains the testicles.
scrotum.function: Regulates the temperature of the testicles for optimal sperm production.

testes.description: The male reproductive glands that produce sperm and hormones, primarily testosterone.

epididymis.description: A coiled tube where sperm matures and is stored.

vas deferens.description: The duct that conveys sperm from the epididymis to the ejaculatory duct.

seminal vesicles.description: Glands that produce a fluid that nourishes sperm and forms a significant part of semen.

prostate gland.description: A gland that surrounds the urethra and produces fluid that nourishes and transports sperm.

bulbourethral glands.description: Glands that produce a pre-ejaculatory fluid that lubricates the urethra.

functions.reproductive: Facilitates sexual reproduction through the production and delivery of sperm.
functions.urinary: Allows for the excretion of urine from the body.

branches.function: Carries blood to the right lung

conditions.name: Pulmonary embolism

conditions.name: Pulmonary hypertension
